Posted: July 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								I actually find myself enjoying this. However it is much more entertaining if you have friends to play with rather than playing solo. That's not to say the isn't good just as a single player title. The format is very similar to old school Metroid/Castlevania (as the description points out). You will find yourself occasionally getting frustrated by some of the old mechanics, like trying to jump back away from a trap, only to still land on said trap because you hit the ceiling and didn't move laterally. I hate giving scores, but I will say this game is certainly for afficionados of classic game play styles. If you enjoyed metroid or castlevania, and want a game that has a lot of detail while at the same time not taking itself too seriously, you'll find fun in this one.

Posted: August 15, 2014
												This game is really fun if you like fun games and don't care alot about graphics.  It provides a challenge all the way through due to greatly varied enemies and challenges throughout.  Also, the game was made much easier over time, but is still challenging on hard.  The story is a joke and had me cracking up lots of times.  There are tons of different weapons and spells.  If you have any common sense and have played rpg games before, then you will be able to manage the skill point system by simply picking one combat skill to keep leveled up and just save the other points for overcoming challenges.  If you are dumb and always spend all your points every level and have a bunch of overlapping skills, then you will have to grind to get points to overcome challenges.  Most of the later challenges can be overcome in multiple ways as well if you just think.  I like that this game encouraged thought and the use of more skills than just a single combat skill like most other games.  If you don't like to think or plan a little, you may not like this game since you will probably get stuck.  The only part that I thought was messed up was the end battle since it doesn't fit the style of the rest of the game.  I recommend slowing the game down using software to beat the last battle since you will fall or get knocked off the platforms and not have enough time.  One bad thing doesn't ruin the game though.  This is a great game and is a good deal when on sale for $5.00.  I wouldn't pay more than $5.00 for it though...

Posted: April 30, 2015
												The game is fun and entertaining from the start as you farm money, quest for legendary items and search for hidden corners in a map! However the later part of the game is just very one sided. For a start, bosses. Literally the only bosses that I could kill using melee was the first worm and the eyeball. The rest was just a magic spam. Secondly, weapon balance. Seriously the bow damage and magic damage difference is just far far too much to the point that I never used a bow the moment I learned my first magic ability. Thirdly, healing. What kind of game doesn't sell potions? Crafting potions asides, why can't I even craft multiple potions all at once?? Its not like monster would come into the caldron room and stab me. And finally, autosaves and manual saves. This is the first offline game I've seen without a manual save which can be very frustrating when you have to walk the previous 2 maps just to get back to where you died because autosave happens in like every ?? minutes. Overall, if you're a melee lover, I won't really recommend this game as half the time, you'd get knocked down from a cliff if you try to smack a target guarding a chest there and so on. But if you're a magic lover, go ahead and get this game, you won't regret this.

Posted: June 16, 2013
Early Access Review
								An excellent 2D RPG! Great humor, plenty of quests, lot's of items, and at the time of writing this, multiplayer is currently in alpha with people currently playing it. To make things clear, the main game is already finished. The "Early Access" part is only for multiplayer, which is still in the works. That's not to say the main game won't be getting anything new, but the multiplayer is the sole reason UnEpic is "Early Access"Exploring the Castle is great fun. Each zone is unique, with it's own unique look, feel, and the enemies that inhabit it.Magic is fun too. A large variety of spells to choose from. My only gripe with the magic system is that if I want to specialize in a certain school of magic, I have to go through the main story in order to get to the point where you initially get that magic. I'm not sure how it works Online, since I haven't played that yet(wanted to finish story).Each zone has multiple side quests you can discover and complete. Each one has it's own little story.There's also multiple pets you can find that will aid you someway in battle.Overall, it's an amazing RPG, definitely worth getting at any price. Along with Online Multiplayer, and the ability to create and share your maps with friends, gives this game a lot of replayability.EDIT(12/25/13): It has been 6 months since I initially wrote this review, and much has changed. While there was partial controller support when I first wrote this, there is now full support, making the game very comfortable to play with the controller, and the keyboard controls are also great.There's is now also voice acting for the vast majority of the game. Some generic environment dialogue has yet to be Voiced, but all Story Dialogue, both Main and Side, are all voiced, along with the tips/tutorial.

Posted: August 3, 2013
Early Access Review
								This game is everything you (may not) have heard it is, and then some.  Truly, this is a gem among treasures, a game that's hard to put down, inherent with solid gameplay, and unexpected but welcome intelligent and witty humor - a combo difficult to pull off, yet done well, effortlessly presented in such a way that I found myself  buying into the character as though he had life.  The approach is original, and the design is unique; a perfectly crafted masterpiece, complimented with inuitive, and responsive controls, all wrapped up in an 2-d (old school) side scrolling adventure.  It delivers a visual style fitting of itself, almost as though it created the style as well, rounding out the package and value even more.  It's simple, yet elegantly crafted, with small details and nuances, it can make an old school gamer smile, that old.... warm smile, a bit of 'thats cool,' from the days when we used words like "rad;" for whatever reason this game nailed something nostalgic, and tapped that old school love, in these modern times.  There is a reason this game is considered one of the top 10 indie games... ever.  If there is a game worth your time, this is likely it.  Simply put, this game is 15 dollars of happiness. .   .    buy it.  I guarantee you will find yourself smiling, I'm just curious how long it will take you to realize it.

Posted: April 27, 2015
												Unepic is a very surprising game.At first glance it really looks like nothing special, however the gameplay relatively soon pulled me right in. It's a metroidvania style 2D game with a strictly defined area map system. It also has quite an interesting story and dialogue, it is self-aware and that makes for some interesting plot points. It is very lighthearted and tries to be comedic, which it somewhat accomplishes. The humour often comes off as crude and childish, plus there are way too many references in the game.For me where the game really shines is the gameplay. It can be quite varied, with your character having the potential to do any type of combat, and you have one possible reset in the second half of the game if you think you want to specialize in another area. Just be sure to stick with the game, since in the beginning you have a very limited skill set which does start to grow, however a bit too slowly for me.I thought the room design was well done and varied throughout the whole castle, which helped in differentiating the areas and keeping your experiences fresh.Sadly there is not a good quest tracker in the game, all it displays is a checklist of your objectives without any further detail. If it's a long quest that you didn't manage to finish right away you might even forget where is the location of the quest giver. Thankfully there's a scroll that you can buy which instantly teleports you to the quest giver, but there really should be no need to buy separate scrolls just because the game doesn't provide you with a good enough overview.Similarly the map is lacking a lot of information. It is possible to put your own comments for each room, however that gets tedious and you don't have the insight into what is important during your first playthrough. There isn't much needed to vastly improve the map, just a couple of icons and maybe some short description of the area, so that you don't have to resort to browsing the internet as to where you should go next because you have no quest and on the map it appears that you don't have anywhere else to go.And that's also one of the biggest faults of the game, it doesn't give you enough information which leaves you to blindly try and brute force it until you give up and look it up on the internet. As before this could've been easily avoided with just a little bit more information.I wouldn't call the faults of the game actual faults, they're more like annoyances. Anyway, I am glad I stuck with the game, and as a result I had a lot of fun with it.7 / 10

Posted: December 22, 2014
												This game is beautiful. This is how most casual (emphasis on "most") would react and act if they were sucked into a Dungeons & Dragons Universe. Each skill is used for something (that's right guys, no more useless skills that you regret leveling later.) Also each weapon is useful for something. Dagger does bonus damage from stabbing in the back, polearms have longer reach, sword swings slightly faster, maces/axes can break hard objects, bows can be used to either pick off enemies at a distance or you can shoot one, get its attention and draw it over to you and dispatch it quietly as to not alert the other enemies. spells actually require materials to use (and you have to learn/earn the ability use each element of magic) The references to other things (such as LoTR, Golden Child, Star Wars) are somewhat subtly put in (whereas some of them are shoved in your face and you are like "Yeah i get it. you are trying to make a reference"). Rather than just being a generic hack and slash, loot collection game this actually has a story. and the side missions are actually worth doing! they give you things that aren't required for the main story but make it easier along the way. For only about $12 this game is well worth the price.

Suffers from a slightly inane sense of humour at times and a dislikeable main character (he is 'that' guy) but can be humourous in parts. ALso has slight balance problems: switches from very easy to very hard in places with very little middle ground.Overall a flawed but fun game.

Posted: July 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Unepic is grand.It plays well, has great humor, interesting story, character progression doesn't feel forced or plain or cheap and since the last update the combat is even more interesting.The aesthetical design feels very natural to the game and meshes well with every part of it.What the singleplayer experience doesn't do very well, is teaching you what the next boss encounter will do.While most of them are pretty straightforward, Neuron for example is the one you will spend alot of time on.You will get really frustrated with Neuron until you experience the "yeah i get it" moment, if you will experience it at all, and beating him will be really difficult unless you read a guide online, because the game doesn't foreshadow his mechanics anyhow. Putting Enemies around the area that selectively reverse your controls, make you randomly chug potions or shoot random spells, at a lesser frequency than the boss would've been a solution to this.Another negative is if you are playing on maximum difficulty, Skeletons will be your worst nightmare. At all times DO NOT FIGHT THEM WITH AN AXE. The problem is that the Axe swings too slowly, and there are alot of Skeletons usually coming your way. They will stunlock you and you won't be able to do jack crap against that and die horribly. But that's the maximum difficulty for you. Invest some points into Hammers because the game reimburses you for that anyway (by giving you more skill points).Nevertheless, the rest of the singleplayer is great and alot of fun.If you are done with singleplayer, better grab a friend and play the multiplayer!With the recent addition of Architecture, you can also make your own multiplayer maps.

Posted: July 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								Took about 30 hours to finish the main campaign and it was worth every minute.  Entertaining/humerous story, good character customization, challenging but not cheap, good variety of enemies and reasons to use different weapons/abilities.Magic is limited by a drop (various colors) called essence, which made it seem more precious then a regenerating mana bar, but not so precious you were hesitant to use it.  Healing was a bit hard to come by so when fighting to the next check point every hit mattered, which reminded me somewhat of the original final fantsy.  You can hearth back to the save point at any time which heals you so you don't get stranded with no health, but you need to make it to a waypoint to really advance.Enemies do respawn but not gratuitously, around 5 screens will stay cleared which prevented combat from getting too tedious.  Pets are extremely useful but also very vulnerable and it costs money to ressurect them which meant using a pet or not using a pet (and which pet to use) was a legitimate decision.  Lighting all the torches in a room, which is then marked on the map, gave a good sense of completeness.    My only real complaint was the shortage of hotkeys.  With a gamepad you get 12, with a keyboard I think you get 15 or 20?  I used a gamepad and 12 wasn't quite enough.  The game does not pause when you go into your inventory or spellbook so reassigning keys on the fly isn't practical.  In most cases this wasn't a problem, but for bosses occasionaly it meant getting owned, and coming back with a couple different abilities/items on your hotbar.Speaking of bosses, most of them were pretty good, there's something like 7 in total plus a couple mini bosses.  Their difficulty surely depends on how you've built your character, one in particular gave me a lot of trouble because I had no way to cure poison.There's also a dungeon editor and multiplayer campaigns if you're craving more after the campaign though I haven't tried them.

Posted: July 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Bought (too) many games in the Summer Sale including UnEpic which I foolishly left uninstalled, thinking it would be just another Rage-Quit, early access bug-ridden type game. 13+ Hours in two days (one, Monday, supposed to be working!) and I simply cannot quit.Not sure what it is but it has something that keeps me waning to see just-a-bit-more. Even when I thought I had found a bug, it turned out to be my lack of understanding (and some pesky thieves). Developers suggest 20 hours of adventures in the single player game, well at my skill level that may be optimistic  - more likely 30 hours +. Added to that multiplayer and the Workshop and I believe you will get value from this title and a lot of fun.

Posted: July 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Despite the resurgence of popularity in Metroidvania-style exploration games, few games take a bold approach the way UnEpic does. Throwing a mish-mash of pop-culture humor into a lighthearted trek through a dungeon, UnEpic's ten or so hours of gameplay are ripe with puzzles, traps and all the usual D&D shennanigans you've come to love and expect out of medieval fantasy.This being said, UnEpic isn't perfect. Boss fights like Neuron are downright infuriating, and some game mechanics like invisible, flying enemies, rooms full of poisonous enemies and a lack of antidotes slow down the pace of the game's last act considerably.UnEpic is anything but, and despite its flaws, shines through as a diamond in the rough.

Posted: July 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								I actually find myself enjoying this. However it is much more entertaining if you have friends to play with rather than playing solo. That's not to say the isn't good just as a single player title. The format is very similar to old school Metroid/Castlevania (as the description points out). You will find yourself occasionally getting frustrated by some of the old mechanics, like trying to jump back away from a trap, only to still land on said trap because you hit the ceiling and didn't move laterally. I hate giving scores, but I will say this game is certainly for afficionados of classic game play styles. If you enjoyed metroid or castlevania, and want a game that has a lot of detail while at the same time not taking itself too seriously, you'll find fun in this one.

Posted: April 14, 2015
												This game just ticks many things I personally like in a game. It's probably not for everyone, though.-metroidvania. It has lots of screens, and quite a lot of room on each screen. While this makes the protagonist pretty small, it's pretty fun once you're used to it. I find myself exploring things much more than in other metroidvania games.-different weapons that actually serve a use. I most other games, you just stick with one or two weapons. Here, the correct approach differs from the enemy. This has a drawback when it comes to leveling, but I like the idea a lot. And you'll need all those shortcuts.-a storyline that somehow both mocks and pays hommage to roleplaying and games. All the meta-references that break immersion in a pen and paper RPG work remarkably well here.-decent level design. with all the unlockable shortcuts, sidequests and torches to be lit, there's always something to do. More than once, I lost track of the direction of the main quest but just went out to do other stuff. It's rare to see that in a platform environment.So...I'm apparently ten hours in. I don't have much of an idea how far I am or what's left to discover, but I just enjoy playing the game (even when all I do is explore a part and then teleport back to the starting point when my health gets too low). I don't think this sort of game is for everyone, but it certainly won me over. :-)

Early Access Review
								Dungeon crawling, teenage humour, and RPG elements, what more can you ask for?Not a rogue like per se, more like a platform RPG, taking some ideas from Metroidvania, is quite entertaining. Lots of items, lots of menus, spells, scrolls, weapons, etc, will keep you busy for hours. My major complain is related with the size of the characters, too small for 2014... Posted: June 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you are a fan of Castlevania, this game is for you! Combining the retro feel of old Castlevanias and the gameplay of newer ones like Symphony of the Night with lots of Easter Eggs and Mature Comedy produces UnEpic. This game is fun, funny, and has a great story line (thus far only 25% into the game). The main character is hilarious, witty, clever, and greedy making him the perfect protagonist in this crazy plot. The combat contains elements not found in many games such as weapon types and resistances, weapon skills, spells, potions, scrolls, and more! There is even an online version to the game that I haven't gotten to try out. I think they were aiming to make it feel like Castlevania Harmony of Despair.Again, if you are a fan of the Castlevania series, you can't go wrong with this gane!

Early Access Review
								Pretty good game for what it is. Player-created maps / workshop support adds unlimited playthrough potential. Most maps recommend 3 players - so hopefully you have some friends to play with, but we've managed with just 2 of us.Really only 4 gripes...1) No direct link to workshop from library - have to visit the community page to find it.2) Not a ton of workshop content (note: this is due to the player base, not the devs).3) Player models look insanely similar. Ocassionally you will lose sight of your person and think you're controlling someone else.4) Only partial controller support. This is a title that should be fully controller implemented - but every now and then (like typing /dice, browsing menus, etc) the controller simply does not work or can't access everything in that menu.Edit:Adding #5.5) Abundant number of spelling mistakes are present in the cooperative "unepic" campaign set of maps.

												This game is overall  fun, witty and generally a good play. Learning the enemy weaknesses will provide a good amount of challenge, as will the numerous bosses. It has several well desgined features, such as the map, and levelling system (even if it could be a bit more forthcoming with those levelling points!) Posted: June 25, 2015
												This game is an action RPG 2D adventure game. It has an interesting story about a roleplayer from our time getting transported to some huge castle, with mysteries, mosters and magic. Many regular tropes get challenged in the story which is especially interesting if you know a lot of typical geek references.The gameplay is insteresting and fun, you level up and it feels rewarding when you find secrets or beat a boss.However there are two huge downsides:1. Game breaking bugs which make quests impossible to complete. I've only found this on sidequests, however it is so extremly frustrating when you run around for 2 hours looking for a quest item, to finaly realize that it was where you found it the first 5 minutes... but you could not pick it up due to a bug.2. The level up system is never explained what the different skills does. This means that, especially if you whant to create a wizard, you may place points in the worng places, which does not seem to be possible to change later.The downsides are unfortuenately too large right now to big. If fixed I would recomend, but as it stands I do not recomend.

Posted: June 22, 2015
												A very good metroid / castlevania like game, stuffed with humor and good dungeon dweeling.The story, although simple, is fun to go through, with interesting characters and most dialogues are voice acted (it adds alot to the game, as you might guess).The game is very difficult but doesn't feel unfair, you always know why you died, and strategy wise, there is a good range of possible weapon and strategy you might use to win (although using some kind of range attack is a must, I personnaly play a fire sword mage). No matter which strategy you choose though, its effectiveness will always be tied to your personnal skills as a gamer, and that's very important for those who play at the highest difficulty (In most of the games, if I see a 'winning' strategy, I'll basically disregard every other aspect of the gameplay and go on owning the content with it)There are secrets and hidden challenges, as well as sidequest you might want to get into to improve your chances of surviving.The music is great also, and the graphics are a mix of vector (during dialogue) and pixel art.Best 2$ I've spent in a longgggg time.

												Since this game was advertised as a Metroidvania style game, and I have enjoyed that genre a great deal in the past I figured I would give this game a go. Sad to say that it seemingly takes the worst aspects of the genre and drops what makes games like Castlevania great.The combat and platforming are very sluggish, leaving little room for dodging or complex maneuvers. The game does accommodate this style of slower more deliberate gameplay, but it leaves little room for interesting enemy dynamics or platforming puzzles. The mechanics never really felt natural as I played, though the difficulty never rose to the point where I had to hone my mechanics or knowledge of the game even on a higher difficulty. The boss fights are pretty simplistic since the game does not expect you to be able to move a great deal. The RPG aspects generally just randomly help or hurt you rather than truly encourage different styles of play. If you decide to go into axes vs. maces, the only real difference will be some enemies take more damage from one. I ended up just saving up points for if a challenge presented itself and I needed to skill differently rather than develop an actual character. The writing is quite awful, perhaps some of the worst I have seen in a game (a quick note to writers, a reference is not a joke), with the low handing fruit of nerd jokes making up a majority of the humor (think Big Bang Theory). So the writing ranges from cringe inducing references (having Admiral Ackbar say “It’s a trap”, literally), to just lazily having Zoidberg run across the screen. The art design is not particularly inspired, with sprite design looking closer to stock images and backgrounds with very little definition or dynamism.There were a few good aspects to the game that kept it appealing for a time. The exploration was crafted with more care than the other areas mentioned above, with a cool lighting mechanic to encourage discovery. The magic system is pretty intricate and has some good ideas tucked in there (though there was some required grinding involved). Overall though the exploration action platformer genre is getting quite light these days, but there are better titles that are not weak in so many areas. I am really disappointed in this title considering its promise.

Early Access Review
								Great Oldschool game with many modern jokes. The Developers really got humor; you can choose between several different languages: the developer is not a native English speaker and he kept his first English translation as an optional "UnEnglish" language before they had a "real" translation.You can play in many different ways and combine the skills as you like --> be an axe-wielding telepath/pyromancer or a crusader-like Necromancer if you wish. My first character is a Swordfighter/Archer/Transmuter/medicore-Healer.Playing different builds and trying to solve the challenges (which reward each of your present and future chars with "UN credits" for special items like a "phaser shooting Spaceship Enterprise familiar") will bind you for hours and hours to this game.One advice for new players: The first Multiplayer scenario (recommended for 3 lvl 1-3 heros) is frustrating since it contains many unfair traps, high hitpoint monster (feels like 3-5 times more compared to single player) and a hard boss if playing it solo (the jokes are nice though; a mean DM leads a greedy pen&paper group)--> start a singleplayer game first and ignore those "the game is unfair and the fights are too hard" Reviews from people that jumped directly in that multiplayer scenario.

Posted: June 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Played for a few hours to check it out.  It's a neat little game.  It almost has an Android phone game feel to it, but don't let the graphics fool you, it's challenging.  It has a Metroid style exploration going for it which is neat, and lots of items and equipment that drop often.  The humor is funny, because instead of playing an Adventurer you're playing a dude pretending to be an Adventurer.  He's a total smartass to everyone he speaks to, making references to all sorts of funny films, comics, and other video games along the way.A few gripes would be that the combat is tough mostly because the jumping mechanic is a little awkward, (controller recommended for sure).  I'm having difficulty remapping the buttons as well because there doesn't seem to be a way to unassign buttons, so trying to assign a button that's already in use actually activates whatever the key does.Another thing that's a little jarring is the overuse of cursing by the main character.  The voice actors are trying their hardest to make do with the script, but really there's no reason for it.  It makes the game come off like it was written by a younger crowd of junior high kids trying to impress an older crowd of high schoolers.  Don't get me wrong, I curse up a storm in real life, but there's a place for it, and it kind of doesn't fit in this game so well.Otherwise, it's amusing and I've laughed out loud a few times, because the references are placed really well and whomever did the translation to English did a great job for their designers.

Posted: June 22, 2014
												I've really enjoyed my time playing UnEpic, and at this point, I haven't even finished the actual game yet. It has a decent level of feeling both grindy and not grindy at times; I had trouble approaching some of the mobs in the game when they were just large groups (especially when they learned how to use ladders), but I felt that the bosses were fair. Bosses in the game were not necessarily long affairs, but slipping up during one of them could prove very punishing. If they were long (>5 minutes), it would be tedious, but I like the balance achieved.There are a few flaws (in my opinion) in this game that I don't think will get 'fixed' for the final product, and in a sense, game balance is one of them. There isn't quite as much freedom as I'd want out of a game like this; the character page looks as if you can follow archetypes such as a mage, but it really won't work for the game as a whole. My character used a balance of range, melee, and magic, and I don't know how I'd fare if I didn't use all three of those. Fortunately, you have enough skill points to have strengths in all those areas. It just means that you, as a player, are quite capable of making a character that might just not be able to stand up to specific challenges.Multiplayer seems like a great idea, and I think the tools used in it show a lot of potential. Better yet, it appears as though the multiplayer is getting the bulk of the attention. Unfortunately, only a really small crowd plays multiplayer; try and get a couple friends to play with you if possible, and it would definitely enhance, if not create, the experience. As of writing this, I haven't quite done that yet. That being said, when I have played with others through finding/making games, I have found the other people to be easy to work with. That might not be the experience across the board, but I imagine that a game like this has less trolls on the multiplayer compared to more popular titles.As for the early access part...I wouldn't have noticed that it was in this stage if it wasn't plastered over the steam page. The single player has always been completely done, and the multiplayer, again, only suffers from lack of players. I could see fear in playing a game nowhere near completion, but the early access was a solid product.All in all, I've played this game for a good amount of time for its price, and I think it makes to be a fun game. It's unforgiving at times, but when it really matters, you can know that you were accountable for messing up most of the time. This game deserves to have a larger crowd, because it's pretty solid; even in its early access. There is a lot of fun to be had.

Posted: August 15, 2014
												This game is really fun if you like fun games and don't care alot about graphics.  It provides a challenge all the way through due to greatly varied enemies and challenges throughout.  Also, the game was made much easier over time, but is still challenging on hard.  The story is a joke and had me cracking up lots of times.  There are tons of different weapons and spells.  If you have any common sense and have played rpg games before, then you will be able to manage the skill point system by simply picking one combat skill to keep leveled up and just save the other points for overcoming challenges.  If you are dumb and always spend all your points every level and have a bunch of overlapping skills, then you will have to grind to get points to overcome challenges.  Most of the later challenges can be overcome in multiple ways as well if you just think.  I like that this game encouraged thought and the use of more skills than just a single combat skill like most other games.  If you don't like to think or plan a little, you may not like this game since you will probably get stuck.  The only part that I thought was messed up was the end battle since it doesn't fit the style of the rest of the game.  I recommend slowing the game down using software to beat the last battle since you will fall or get knocked off the platforms and not have enough time.  One bad thing doesn't ruin the game though.  This is a great game and is a good deal when on sale for $5.00.  I wouldn't pay more than $5.00 for it though...

Posted: July 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Great game. Variable difficulty levels let you choose what kind of experience you'd like. Very similar to castelvania games from years ago. Provides ample challenge, without being impossible. Lots of skills/spells, weapons all have varied damage types and speeds. You can tell this game has gotten a lot of thought.Sometimes monster hitboxes feel funny. It is possible to get into a state where an enemy has slightly longer reach than you, hits you and knocks you back, then hits you again just before you get in range. It feels like even a trash enemy on your way to a boss fight or merchant can take down a lot of health if you get stuck in a cycle like that. Though it is also possible to lock many enemies in a stunned state with your own strikes. So it isn't biased toward one side. Boss fights can be very hard if you don't have skill points in a necessary weapon or spell type, due to the significant impact of resistances.

Posted: June 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've only just beaten the first boss (on the ages 16+ side of the game and Hard++ difficulty), and have not been dissappointed so far. There have been multiple references to pop-culture, as the description states, and a plethora of humorous back-and-forth dialogue between the protagonist and the spirit that failed to possess him, becoming helplessly trapped within his body. There have also been a few points where I was given options on how to proceed, but to avoid spoilers, I won't go into any details.The gameplay itself is overall pretty decent and reminiscent of side-scrolling Castlevania games, save for the inability to move horizontally while attacking. Due to this lack of mobility on horizontal attacks, I would highly recommend using any weapon with a longer reach or a ranged attack when attempting to fight stationary opponents, snakes in particular (so far) due to their ability to stack poison debuffs on you.If you enjoy side-scrolling, platformer RPGs, then I would recommend the buy, despite currently being in Early Access. I've unfortunately not tried the multiplayer side of the game yet, but hope it's just as entertaining as the single player has been so far.    -- 8 / 10 --

Posted: July 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								Note:  although this is an early access review, the single player mode is 100% complete and implemented.  I have not tried out the multiplayer yet but it looks very promising.This game does so many things right, which make its flaws all the more annoying.  I loved the exploration, lighting all the torches, making notes on my map.  The frustrating aspect comes from some design decisions made by the developer.  The biggest thing is there is a boss about a third of the way through the game that is impossible to fight from range (among other annoyances, but I won't spoil those in this review).  Later in the game, there are bosses impossible to fight in melee.  I wouldn't be as annoyed by this except you can only respec once in the entire game.  Even after respeccing you have to drop loads of gold to get the new skills, equipment, or essences (for casting spells).  If you're going to play this, definitely multi-class.  I made it through with swords, maces, and bows.  In particular, you can find a hidden bow about 2/3rds of the way through that will easily carry you to the end of the game.  I can see pure caster characters being fairly strong as well, but you might have to grind more for casting mats.Anyway, I will give this game a thumbs up.  It has a lot of charm and brought me back to the feeling of classic NES/SNES metroidvanias.  Pick it up if you're a fan of the genre.

Posted: October 13, 2015
												Finally finished the game so I can write a review! Damn was I looking forward to that because... YES! That game is great!To sum it up to you:- this is an indie metroid/castlevania like action-platformer-RPG!- go back and forth with your character in a HUGE dungeon- loot, craft and buy/sell TONS of items, weapons, spells...- evolve the traditional way you want (fighter, mage, rogue...) and you better only focus on one- fight very hard enemies and ultra painful bosses from whom you always have to learn and remember the patterns if you hope to survive- hop and jump on platforms, gather keys and check your map- find many optional quests, NPC, hidden challenges so freaking hard to beat- enjoy (or not) the somehow (just a bit) unusual story and its many written dialoguesSaid like that, it sounds like the usual stuff, right? but here is the thing: the game was made by one guy, and its oldschoolness is so authentic that the game is great. If you enjoy the real traditional stuff, UnEpic IS epic and great. It is sometimes as hard as Ghouls & Ghosts, as overwhelming as Super Metroid, and as rich and long as an old Castlevania on NES or a long night table RPG.YES it has flaws. As I said, the game was made by one guy, and you can (sometimes) feel it:- the game is very repetitive but as could be great action games on NES- the story and its dialogues are a bit vulgar, and heavy,  I guess it's the Spanish way (free hit! wink) but I even turned off the voices after 10 hours in the game because they annoyed me and wanted to enjoy a more traditional approach- in that same idea the artwork is sometimes clumsy or even mediocre, but as a board game fan it is something I can look past, and I guess the next game will be prettier- the game is sometimes (rarely) too easy if you find a good build up combo for you character (I was a rogue with a magical dagger and... a huge axe, yeah), and on the contrary it is sometimes (often) much too hard (I am looking at you, last boss Medeox!), but for me and the people who love old-school challenges, what a pleasure it is to yell at a boss that you try to beat for the 19th time and when you finally succeed you get out of the room and get one-shot by a lame enemy before having the chance to save your progress! GRAAAHHHAJHDKJHFJEGFYUGé&"'-(é&""!!!!?)Overall, Steam says I spent 50 hours on it, the game tells me 30 hours, so the truth must lie in between, but you WILL spend tens of hours on it if you are not a pro gamer. And man, in 2015, spend 40 hours on an indie game just to finish the main story, how rare and exquisite is that?!You used to enjoy Metroid, Castlevania, G&G on NES/SNES and you want to dive into a great, real indie, old school, hard and tiresome action/platform/rpg? I DO RECOMMEND that game!

Posted: October 13, 2015
												I cannot recommend this game. Too much of it is broken or poorly designed. There's too much grinding for recipe ingredients, boss battles and other enemies have the artificial difficulty of undefendable attacks that can't be seen coming, getting off ladders is unpredictable and unreliable if you're not at the top or bottom, some enemies are borderline invisible (dark enemies against dark background in the dark), the action can be squint-worthy if at standard (not closer) zoom (and some boss battles and ranged enemies require standard zoom), enemies can juggle you with multiple unstoppable attacks coming in a row. There's just a lot of padding with artificial difficulty and simply unenjoyable "challenge" from maybe one quarter or one third of the way in (I made it about halfway).Don't buy this game. Save your money. It's too old to have this many unfixed problems.

												fantastic voice overs. great gameplay (metroidvania style) plenty of loot, from plain to legendary and all categories in between, fantastic characters and bosses that range in difficulty (I played in Hard ++) the levels are varied and the soundtracks are OUTSTANDING. potions system and weapons that are useful in different situations. the plot and some twists and it has multiple endings. Posted: December 22, 2014
												This game is beautiful. This is how most casual (emphasis on "most") would react and act if they were sucked into a Dungeons & Dragons Universe. Each skill is used for something (that's right guys, no more useless skills that you regret leveling later.) Also each weapon is useful for something. Dagger does bonus damage from stabbing in the back, polearms have longer reach, sword swings slightly faster, maces/axes can break hard objects, bows can be used to either pick off enemies at a distance or you can shoot one, get its attention and draw it over to you and dispatch it quietly as to not alert the other enemies. spells actually require materials to use (and you have to learn/earn the ability use each element of magic) The references to other things (such as LoTR, Golden Child, Star Wars) are somewhat subtly put in (whereas some of them are shoved in your face and you are like "Yeah i get it. you are trying to make a reference"). Rather than just being a generic hack and slash, loot collection game this actually has a story. and the side missions are actually worth doing! they give you things that aren't required for the main story but make it easier along the way. For only about $12 this game is well worth the price.

If it's not on sale, it's worth buying, if it is on sale, It's a no brainer.

Posted: December 23, 2014
												I would recommend this game to anyone who likes Metroidvanias, with the one caveat that the story is absolutely terrible. Turn off the voice acting, and skip through the text as fast as you can. It tries to be funny by hammering home the same dumb joke over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over. The main player is crude and the spirit is annoyed by this. I GET IT. They're a regular old Odd Couple. The problem is the Odd Couple had jokes, and this just has references to things, hoping the reader might find the references funny. It's a very fun game. It plays a little stiffer than Metroid or Castlevania, but it's more of a slow paced platform dungeon crawler than those games. It feels just different enough to be new. I just wish it had no dialogue whatsoever. Oh, it's also pretty visually unappealing, but that's just what you get with these retro-ish games.

Posted: August 15, 2014
												This game is really fun if you like fun games and don't care alot about graphics.  It provides a challenge all the way through due to greatly varied enemies and challenges throughout.  Also, the game was made much easier over time, but is still challenging on hard.  The story is a joke and had me cracking up lots of times.  There are tons of different weapons and spells.  If you have any common sense and have played rpg games before, then you will be able to manage the skill point system by simply picking one combat skill to keep leveled up and just save the other points for overcoming challenges.  If you are dumb and always spend all your points every level and have a bunch of overlapping skills, then you will have to grind to get points to overcome challenges.  Most of the later challenges can be overcome in multiple ways as well if you just think.  I like that this game encouraged thought and the use of more skills than just a single combat skill like most other games.  If you don't like to think or plan a little, you may not like this game since you will probably get stuck.  The only part that I thought was messed up was the end battle since it doesn't fit the style of the rest of the game.  I recommend slowing the game down using software to beat the last battle since you will fall or get knocked off the platforms and not have enough time.  One bad thing doesn't ruin the game though.  This is a great game and is a good deal when on sale for $5.00.  I wouldn't pay more than $5.00 for it though...

Posted: December 22, 2014
												This game is beautiful. This is how most casual (emphasis on "most") would react and act if they were sucked into a Dungeons & Dragons Universe. Each skill is used for something (that's right guys, no more useless skills that you regret leveling later.) Also each weapon is useful for something. Dagger does bonus damage from stabbing in the back, polearms have longer reach, sword swings slightly faster, maces/axes can break hard objects, bows can be used to either pick off enemies at a distance or you can shoot one, get its attention and draw it over to you and dispatch it quietly as to not alert the other enemies. spells actually require materials to use (and you have to learn/earn the ability use each element of magic) The references to other things (such as LoTR, Golden Child, Star Wars) are somewhat subtly put in (whereas some of them are shoved in your face and you are like "Yeah i get it. you are trying to make a reference"). Rather than just being a generic hack and slash, loot collection game this actually has a story. and the side missions are actually worth doing! they give you things that aren't required for the main story but make it easier along the way. For only about $12 this game is well worth the price.

Posted: April 2, 2015
												A fun and strangely addictive platformer RPG; the graphical style and inventory management reminded me a lot of Terraria (although UnEpic is not a randomized open-world game like that). I appreciated the ability to add notes to the in-game map, a feature so few games have.It's humour invokes plenty of pop-culture references (and amusing guest appearances)... but be warned: the humour is sometimes surprisingly juvenile... the f-bombs, racial stereotypes and lewd sexual situations seem jarring sometimes in this environment. (There is an option to say you are under 16 years-old when you first run the game, which may actually fix this complaint if it removes the edgier stuff...)

Posted: December 8, 2014
												UnEpic is one of my absolute favorite games. Now, it's not one that I'm going to spend hundreds upon hundreds of hours on, but that's not what it's meant to be. However, there is still a possibility of that if you get involved in the multiplayer scene and start making maps. Personally my experience is limited to playing the single player campaign and soloing the first multiplayer Dungeon because I couldn't find anyone to play with. The story itself is actually rather surprising later on, and you get hints throughout the whole game that perhaps everything is not what it seems. That said, there are a lot of silly, immature, and even downright stupid things said by the protagonist. Of course, he himself (and the entirety of this game) is a parody of the a-typical gamer (and RPG). If you are looking for something that is both entertaining, in-depth, and doesn't take itself too seriously, then this is definitely a game you should check out.

Posted: December 7, 2015
												*****Slight vague spoiler pertaining to the end*****TLDR: Game is solid and enjoyably nostalgic, but the ending is a big FU in difficulty and unexpected strategy which can be nearly impossible if you failed to stat correctly. I was suggested this game while it was dirt cheap. So of course, I bought and started playing. It also made my fancy tickle by being available on linux so I could play it on my Chromebook. I was thoroughly enjoying the game there for a long time. I went through and found all the secrets and developed my character into a solid tank-ranger. I find magic to often be a cheap way to play many games, as it is usually overpowered. As well, to change things up from my usual game playing selections... I chose to go hammer/halberd combo. Come the end... I realized the mistakes that I have made. I already used my item to stat reset and am currently SOL at the end. Since I didn't use magic (literally at all unless absolutely necessary) I struggle to use the alternate guy's heavy magic. I can sprint with my main guy pretty well, but I've never actually been able to beat the end. I just can't keep either one to survive long enough. When it comes down to it, I really did enjoy this game, but the end is so incredibly unexpected with it's difficulty. There is really nothing in the game that seems to compare to the frustrations that the end will bring. After investing a few hours into attempting the end (and seeing the same friggin cut-scene video over and over again) I simply gave up and haven't gone back.

Posted: January 3, 2016
												"Wow, the end is really cool!".Now that that's out of the way I most certainly will not end up in the icebucket of my freezer.I don't write Reviews very often, let me get to thePros:+ Funny AF+ Nice Difficulty, meaning you can't just brute force everything+ Crazy Amount of Spells and Opportunities to use them effectively+ Different Weapon Types with different handling+ ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of interesting Monsters which you have to encounter in various ways+ Many, many (!!) references which are laid out in a humourous way+ Awesome and moodsetting Graphics for a Platformer+ There are Challenges ingame which are really challenging+ Interface - you can keep track of everything: buffs, essences (for spells), log, quests and description field of items+ Inventory has a decent size and is expandable+ Many Sidequests which vary a lot, each is unique and well made+ Sounds: BGMusic is very nice and fits perfectly into the areas and the sound effects (opening doors etc.) are awesome!+ Boss Encounters: Let me put it this way, later ingame I found myself thinking how to counter certain mechanics and  spent few minutes of preparation (stacking up buffs etc.), which Scroll to use - it's challenging but doable.+ Price! This game costs like 13€ and was for me more enjoyable than most full price titles.+ Playtime: I beat the game in 25h, not doing any challenges or having replayed, which i'm gonna!+ Replayability: You can skill your Character so differently that there's a huge variation of playstiles, not just melee/mage+ Freedom in endgame to farm your char to powerlevels over 9000!+ Alchemy: Crafting runs mostly on Mob drops like bat wings for healing potions.+ Accessability and "fast travel" through the castle via Gates and Teleportscrolls or -magic.+ Steam Workshop!!!+ CoopCons:- first encounter with a  Jester  :D Buy it, play it, enjoy it.10/10

Posted: July 18, 2016
												UnEpic is a non-linear RPG platformer. UnEpic begins with the game’s hero, an average guy called Daniel, playing an RPG fantasy board game with his friends. When Daniel heads to the bathroom, the lights go out and Daniel finds himself transported to a castle. Daniel shrugs this off as a hallucination and plays along with the cast of weird and wonderful characters he meets on his journey as fantasy. Daniel learns that his ultimate goal is progress through the castle and to slay its master – Harnakon.UnEpic’s levels look like an 8-bit adventure game, littered with enemies, traps and rewards for the intrepid adventurer. The standard RPG components are in this game like: earning XP, upgrade abilities with points, making potions, learning spells, trading and encounter many different (funny) types of side quests.The game tries its best to poke fun at itself, making jokes about the genre that it’s paying homage to, with nods to the classics weaved into the dialogue between Daniel and Anokra Bash. UnEpic would be an excellent addition to any RPG fans library. UnEpic could ultimately be compared to 8-bit Marmite; if you love RPGs you’ll enjoy it – hate them and it’ll leave a bitter taste in your mouth and hunger for something different.

Posted: January 26, 2016
												I have way too many steam games after all the sales and bundles, a lot of which I know very little about.  I saw unepic mentioned a few times on reddit as something people enjoyed, and I was happy to find it in my library.  It's one of those games you might never play without a recomendation to do so, and I'm glad I gave it a chance.If you like symphony of the night, this is a great little game to spend a few days on.   There is a ton of flexability in what types of skills and abilities you can upgrade, allowing for all sorts of fun charecter builds.  I also like little touches, like being able to write notes on the map.As for negatives, there are a few anoying aspects of the game.  Some bosses require ranged or melee, which can mess with your build, and there are some very anoying status effects and late game mechanics that are more pain than inovation.  It's not a masterpiece, but the game is fun if you like upgrading and leveling up.  And wow, the end is really cool!

Posted: February 21, 2016
												Played this on Hard++ on my first run-through. I can see how this game can be enjoyable on lower difficulties as there is a wide variety of builds that can be used to successfully get through the entire game. With that said: DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME ON HARD++ IF YOU WANT TO HAVE ANY FUN!! If slamming your face into concrete repeatedly for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles is something you're into, go ahead and play this on Hard++. There are only a few specific ways you can build your character towards the last areas of the game on this difficulty. You do get one chance to reset your build after discovering this, but if you are into this game for the variety and creative ways of killing random♥♥♥♥♥♥ you aren't going to have a good time on Hard++. Overall, gameplay was nice (except for a few areas toward the end), story sucks, characters are not interesting. Get it on a sale if still interested, don't pick up at full price -- or just stay away from this one.

Posted: February 19, 2015
												I picked this title up as a random "cheap" buy with the view to getting a few hours of amusement out of it and have been pleasantly suprised at just how good a game it is. I'd never come accross the "Metroidvania" style before, probably as the original titles never grabbed my interest when they first appeared, but as a gameplay style, it feels part way between an RPG and a platformer (and I'll put my hands up and freely admit.. I've never liked platformers).UnEpic scores because you don't have to be as pin sharp accurate with position to avoid a drop to the immediate death and in any case, death here is more of an midly annoying embuggerance than a "hurl D pad at the wall in frustrated rage".The combat rewards thinking and planning rather than button mashing hack and slash (not that hack and slash doesn't work.. it does, it's just you'll get more out of thinking and tactics) and the exploring, challenges and puzzles spice up the variety of tasks.The biggest draws for me though, are the humor, in-jokes and totally inappropriate pop culture references.. The single player game is chock full to bursting with cryingly funny moments and for anyone who grew up with D & D (especially if like me you started with the 1974 original rules) and has ever suffered from the sociopathic DM and his killer dungeon, the whole multiplayer game will have you crying with nostalgic laughter.10/10 for ingenuity, creative gameplay and top notch humor to beat the winter blues.

Posted: April 14, 2015
												This game just ticks many things I personally like in a game. It's probably not for everyone, though.-metroidvania. It has lots of screens, and quite a lot of room on each screen. While this makes the protagonist pretty small, it's pretty fun once you're used to it. I find myself exploring things much more than in other metroidvania games.-different weapons that actually serve a use. I most other games, you just stick with one or two weapons. Here, the correct approach differs from the enemy. This has a drawback when it comes to leveling, but I like the idea a lot. And you'll need all those shortcuts.-a storyline that somehow both mocks and pays hommage to roleplaying and games. All the meta-references that break immersion in a pen and paper RPG work remarkably well here.-decent level design. with all the unlockable shortcuts, sidequests and torches to be lit, there's always something to do. More than once, I lost track of the direction of the main quest but just went out to do other stuff. It's rare to see that in a platform environment.So...I'm apparently ten hours in. I don't have much of an idea how far I am or what's left to discover, but I just enjoy playing the game (even when all I do is explore a part and then teleport back to the starting point when my health gets too low). I don't think this sort of game is for everyone, but it certainly won me over. :-)

Posted: April 23, 2015
												At first I really wasn't sure about it since I've got it for nearly nothing out of a humble bundle but after getting trolled by the game and died three time in a row, I started to understand what kind of funny/exploration/rogue-like/DarkSoulesque side-scroller adventure UnEpic was.After two hours, I've unlocked 2 zone,many weapons,a couple of armor pieces,potion recipes and walked around naked while slaying unforgiving enemies & environment, yes you read that right, walking around naked. I enjoy the kind of humor they've put in place,since your character is a real geek, there's lots of reference to video games,movies & popular culture. So far so good, for 13$ I think it deffinetely worth it with the single player only but there's more to it as you can play it online too, co-op or pvp, official campaign or fan made maps !
